titleStmt.title: Territory of Washington v. Mary E. Teller. James Glispen Testimony

publicationStmt.authority: Bring Me the Body: A Digital & Print History of Marginalized Habeas Corpus Petitioners in the North American West, 1804-1912

bibl.title: Territory of Washington v. Mary E. Teller. James Glispen Testimony
bibl.note: Our transcription is based on a digital image of the microfilmed original.
Multiple case files included with habeas petition

msIdentifier.repository: Washington State Archives, Eastern Regional Branch
msIdentifier.collection: Spokane County Government; Clerk, Territorial Case Files, 1879-1889

div1.p: James Glispen being first duly sworn and examined on oath by the undersigned one of the justices of the Peace on his oath complains and says:

That on the 31st day of May 1887 at the County of Spokane and Territory of Washington one Mary Teller then and there being personaly and of her deliberate and pre-meditated malice killed Frank Teller then and there being by striking, beating, and mortally wounding him the said Frank Teller with a piece of wood and some other weapon to complaniant unknown which she said Mary Teller then and there held in her hand of which mortal wounding the said Frank Teller then and there instantly died. Contrary to the form of the statute in such case made and provided and against the Peace and dignity of the Territory of Washington and Complaniant prays that the said Mary Teller may be arrested and dealt with according to law.
Suscribed and sworn to before me the 4th day of June 1887
